newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria c.bank seeks auctions for bad debt bonds.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria c.bank seeks auctions for bad debt bonds.

text.p: The Bulgarian National Bank (BNB) will propose to the government to amend regulations for trade in domestic bad debt bonds for the sake of greater transparency, a central bank official said on Monday.

"The BNB board proposes that bad debt bonds be traded through auctions at the BNB, aiming at greater transparency of trade in this type of government securities," Nikolina Micheva, head of State Credits department at the BNB, told Reuters.
Bad debt bond auctions would be launched after the finance ministry and the government approve the proposed changes, said Micheva.
Financial institutions now trade lev- and dollar denominated bad debt bonds, called ZUNKs, on a bilateral basis.
The BNB said in a statement it would not sell dollar-denominated bad debt bonds from its portfolio at the planned auctions.
Bad debt bonds worth 32 billion levs and $1.8 billion respectively were issued three years ago to cover banks' non-performing loans extended to state companies before 1991.

Investors' interest in the bonds has been running high because the bonds are accepted as means of payment in local sell-offs at par while their minimum acceptable prices are set at 35 percent for lev bonds and 45 percent for dollar bonds.

Interest in the bonds rose further after the interim cabinet last month raised to 80 percent from 50 percent the maximum stake that can be paid in with ZUNKs in sell-offs of local state small and medium-size firms.
Foreign investors bought $128 million worth of dollar dennominated ZUNKs in March and April, central bank figures showed. Figures for May were not available.

The total par of dollar-denominated ZUNKs in circulation at end-March was $939.6 million and lev-denominated bonds amounted to around 20 billion levs worth. -- Anastas Petrov, Sofia Newsroom +359-2 91188
